article.headline: Arizona State 82, Southern Utah 62
article.story: TEMPE, Ariz. (AP) -- Asked to replace the biggest star Arizona State has had for years, Craig Austin rose to the challenge. Austin scored 21 points in his first start at the post position where Ike Diogu, last season's Pac-10 player of the year, dominated for three years, and the Sun Devils cruised to an 82-62 win over depleted Southern Utah on Wednesday night. "It didn't surprise me, because that's what he's been doing all fall," coach Rob Evans said. "He's improved a lot in the same vein as (1998-2002 center) Chad Prewitt, and that's what we're trying to do. But he's been getting better and more confident all along." Bryson Krueger had 18 points in the Sun Devils' opener, and Kevin Kruger added 14 and six assists. But the spotlight was on Austin, who stayed on campus last summer lifting weights to add 20 pounds for his assignment -- pick up after Ike Diogu left for the NBA draft. The 6-foot-10 sophomore was efficient, hitting 8-of-10 field goals and 5-of-6 free throws. "It's not really pressure. It's more like it's a goal," Austin said. "I mean, Ike's a huge player, but I don't think we can look at it like, 'OK, now we've got to have other people step up.' Now we're more of a guard-oriented team, so I think that's really helped us." Henry Uhegwu had 16 points and Steve Barnes 14 for the Thunderbirds (0-4), who completed a difficult road trip after losing to Mississippi, South Carolina State and New Mexico over the weekend. They began the game without injured starters Rand Janes and Lubor Olsovsky and lost leading scorer Justin Allen when an elbow by Arizona State's Serge Angounou broke his nose and cut his cheek with 4:23 left in the first half. "I'm not making excuses," Southern Utah coach Bill Evans said. "We've been on the road for six days, and Arizona State is not a bad basketball team. I knew that they would cause us difficulties with their pressure, but I didn't think they would cause us that many. They didn't let us run anything we wanted to run, basically." The Thunderbirds recovered from a 48-28 halftime deficit to play Arizona State even in the second half. But Austin kept things under control, scoring 13 points in the second and sinking the Sun Devils' only basket during a 16-8 surge that got the Thunderbirds within 76-58 with 2:03 left. Austin had eight points in the first 6:40 of the game, then went scoreless during a 22-5 run capped by Krueger's 8-foot runner that lifted Arizona State to a 39-14 lead with 3:44 left in the first half. Uhegwu made two free throws and a 3-pointer in 22 seconds, but Krueger restored the 25-point lead at 48-23 with another runner and a 3-pointer, sinking the long shot with 1:04 to go, before the Thunderbirds got within 20 points at halftime. "I think we kind of let up in the last few minutes of the first and second half," Austin said. "I think we could have played a lot better defense. But overall we came out very strong in both halves, so we feel good about that. We just have to keep it up."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
